### clampMaxNumElementsStrict() {#a875edaec1f61b358e8026a4b50de8ea8}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>LegalizeRuleSet &amp; llvm::LegalizeRuleSet::clampMaxNumElementsStrict (unsigned TypeIdx, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/llt">LLT</a> EltTy, unsigned NumElts)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Express <code>EltTy</code> vectors strictly using vectors with <code>NumElts</code> elements (or scalars when <code>NumElts</code> equals 1).

First pad with undef elements to nearest larger multiple of <code>NumElts</code>. Then perform split with all sub-instructions having the same type. Using clampMaxNumElements (non-strict) can result in leftover instruction with different type (fewer elements then <code>NumElts</code> or scalar). No effect if the type is not a vector.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/include/llvm/codegen/globalisel/legalizerinfo-h/#l01285">1285</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/include/llvm/codegen/globalisel/legalizerinfo-h">LegalizerInfo.h</a>.

Limit the number of elements for the given vectors to at least MinTy&#39;s number of elements and at most MaxTy&#39;s number of elements.

No effect if the type is not a vector or does not have the same element type as the constraints. The element type of MinTy and MaxTy must match.

### lowerIfMemSizeNotByteSizePow2() {#a5361d650c0e9459b1dc4c3afec8251ef}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>LegalizeRuleSet &amp; llvm::LegalizeRuleSet::lowerIfMemSizeNotByteSizePow2 ()</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Lower a memory operation if the memory access size is not a round power of 2 byte size.

This is stricter than lowerIfMemSizeNotPow2, and more likely what you want (e.g. this will lower s1, s7 and s24).

### TypeIdxsCovered {#ad08bf7bbc8e9c86df9c5074a7ba64082}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>SmallBitVector llvm::LegalizeRuleSet::TypeIdxsCovered &#123;<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/mcoi/#ad9dfed338ec3d47f30c593ee49cbf96da8b1f03c574eba95352f9e531dbad42b4">MCOI::OPERAND&#95;LAST&#95;GENERIC</a> -
                                 <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/mcoi/#ad9dfed338ec3d47f30c593ee49cbf96da9c1b4fee0481848b7ede086f9bba9ded">MCOI::OPERAND&#95;FIRST&#95;GENERIC</a> + 2&#125;</>}>
If bit I is set, this rule set contains a rule that may handle (predicate or perform an action upon (or both)) the type index I.

The uncertainty comes from free-form rules executing user-provided lambda functions. We conservatively assume such rules do the right thing and cover all type indices. The bitset is intentionally 1 bit wider than it absolutely needs to be to distinguish such cases from the cases where all type indices are individually handled.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/include/llvm/codegen/globalisel/legalizerinfo-h/#l00447">447</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/include/llvm/codegen/globalisel/legalizerinfo-h">LegalizerInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
